Behavioral Factors

Download a PDF of all Behavioral Factors Outcome studies (link TBD)

Social mobilization and social marketing to promote NaFeEDTA-fortified soya sauce in an iron-deficient population through a public-private partnership

Wang B, Zhan S, Sun J, Lee L
Public Health Nutrition, 2008, 12 (10): 1751-1759
Location Shijiazhuang Municipality, Hebei Province, China
Population Women older than 20 years of age and young children aged from 3 to 7 years
Intervention Description Social mobilization and social marketing of iron fortified soya sauce
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: After 1 year, most knowledge and attitudes had changed positively towards the prevention and control of anaemia.

Behaviors: The percentage of women who adopted NaFeEDTA-fortified soya sauce increased from 8.9% to 36.6%.

Health: After 2 years, Hb levels had increased substantially, by 9.0 g/l in adult women and 7.7 g/l in children
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Competition, Methods mix

Social Marketing Improved the Consumption of Iron-fortified Soy Sauce among Women in China

Sun X, Guo Y, Wang S, Sun J
Journal of Nutrition Education and Behavior, 2007, 39 (6): 302-310
Location Guizhou Province, China
Population 372 women between 19 and 70
Intervention Description Mall media compaign to promote use of Iron -fortified soy sauce (FeSS)
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Knowledge of the characteristics of FeSS, Perceptions, attitudes, intentions, availabilty of FeSS

Behaviors: Compared with the baseline survey, the rates of eating and purchasing FeSS increased significantly in both rural areas and urban areas in the follow-up survey. The increases in the 2 experimental groups were significantly higher than those of the 2 control groups
Design Experimental
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 6
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 7: Behavior, Customer, Theory, orientation, Insight, Segmentation, Exchange, Competition, Methods mix

Industry Experience in Promoting Weekly Iron-Folic Acid Supplementation in the Philippines

Garcia J, Datol-Barrett E, Dizon M
Nutrition Reviews, 2005 63 (12), S146-S151
Location Philippines
Population Women of reproductive age
Intervention Description Social marketing of a weekly iron-folic acid supplement for pregnant and non-pregnant women under the brand name Femina
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Brand awareness

Behaviors: In the pilot, of the 40% who had heard of Femina, 44% tried the product, and 59% used the product often
Design Observational
Sampling Method Purposive
Strength of Evidence Score 2
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Competition, Segmentation, Methods mix

Weekly Iron-Folic Acid Supplementation to Improve Iron Status and Prevent Pregnancy Anemia in Filipino Women of Reproductive Age: The Philippine Experience through Government and Private Partnership

Paulino LS, Angeles-Agdeppa I, Etorma UM, Ramos AC, Cavalli- Sforza T
Nutrition Reviews, 2005, 63 (Supplement S2): S109-S115
Location Pangasinan, Philippines
Population Women of Reproductive Age
Intervention Description Social marketing intervention to increase KAP and use of Iron-Folic Acid tablets
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Changes in knowledge and attitudes about anemia,
Design Observational
Sampling Method Purposive
Strength of Evidence Score 1
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 7: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Segmentation, Exchange, Competition, Methods mix

Community Mobilization and Social Marketing to Promote Weekly Iron-Folic Acid Supplementation: A New Approach Toward Controlling Anemia Among Women of Reproductive Age in Vietnam

Khan NC, Thanh HTK, Berger J, Hoa PT, Quant ND, Smitasiri S, Cavalli-Sforza T
Nutrition Reviews, 2005, 63 (Supplement S2): S87-S94
Location Thanh Mien district
Population Women of reproductive age
Intervention Description Intervention using social marketing to increase use of Iron-Folic acid tablets and KAP of anemia, including free distribution to pregnant women
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Changes in knowledge and attitudes about anemia, buying practices increased from 54.5% to 92% among non pregnant women
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Segmentation, Exchange, Methods mix

Weekly Iron-Folic Acid Supplements to Prevent Anemica among Cambodian Women in Three settings: Process and Outcomes of Social Marketing and Community Mobilization

Kanal K, Busch-Hallen J, Cavalli-Sforza T, Crape B, Smitasiri S
Nutrition Reviews, 2005, 63 (Supplement S2): S126-S133
Location Cambodia
Population Women of reproductive age/secondary schoolgirls/garment factory workers/ rural village women
Intervention Description Social marketing mobilization program to promote Iron-Folic Acid supplement use and educate women about Anemia
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Improved knowledge, attitudes, and beliefs about iron tablets at follow up

Design Observational
Sampling Method Purposive
Strength of Evidence Score 1
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 5: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Segmentation, Methods mix

Weekly Iron-Folic Acid Supplementation of Women of Reproductive Age: Impact Overview, Lessons Learned, Expansion Plans, and Contributions Toward Achievement of the Millennium Development Goals

Cavalli-Sforza T, Berger J, Smitasiri S, Viteri F
International Life Sciences Institute, 2005, 63 (12): S152-8
Location Philippines, Camboida, Vietnam
Population Women of reproductive age
Intervention Description Using social marketing to promote weekly Iron-Folic acid supplements through IEC materials and events.
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Understanding of anemia and iron folic acid supplements incrased in all three countries

Behaviors: Use of weekly iron folic acid supplements

Health: In Vietnam Iron deficiency and iron deficiency anaemia significantly decreased among non pregant WRA taking weekeing iron folic acid supplements; in Phillipines significant improvments in serum ferritin among pregnant and non pregnant women taking weeking iron-folic acid supplements; In Cambodia, Hb levels increased among school girls but not among working or rural women
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 4: Behavior, Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix

Social Marketing Improved the Use of Multivitamin and Mineral Supplements among Resource-Poor Women in Bolivia

Warnick E, Dearden KA, Slater S, Butrón B, Lanata CF, Huffman SL
Journal of Nutrition Education and Behavior, 2004, 36 (6): 290-297
Location Bolivia
Population Women 15 to 49 years old
Intervention Description Social marketing campaign for multivitamin and mineral supplements, including VitalDia, using radio and television spots
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Increase in awareness of multivitamins, including VitalDia, the brand promoted as part of this social marketing campaign

Behaviors: After 9 months of social marketing, 11% of women had taken VitalDia one or more times, 7% had taken it at least once in the last 3 months, and 4% had used it one or more times in the last month
Design Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 5
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 7: Behavior, Theory, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix

Involving husbands in safe motherhood: effects of the SUAMI SIAGA campaign in Indonesia

Shefner-Rogers CL, Sood S
Journal of Health Communication, 2004, 9(3): 233-58
Location Indonesia
Population Primary audience: Men of reproductive age; Secondary audience: married women of reproductive age, community leaders and groups, midwives
Intervention Description Mass Media Campaign: PSA Television, Radio Broadcast, Print Material
Outcomes

Behavioral Factors: Exposure to campaign, Changes in knowledge and information-seeking and information-sharing behaviors

Behaviors: Percent of men reporting helping a women who was experiencing pregnancy complications
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 2
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 6: Behavior, Theory Customer orientation, Insight, Segmentation, Methods mix
